title: â€˜Anacondaâ€™ Director on Those Original Cast Cameos, Making Fun of Hollywood Reboots and Reusing a Cyclone-Destroyed Set
summary: SPOILER ALERT: This story discusses spoilers for â€œAnaconda,â€ now playing in theaters When co-writers Tom Gormican and Kevin Etten first pitched what would become their reimagined take on the so-bad-itâ€™s-good 1997 classic â€œAnaconda,â€ they never thought Sony would be on board with the idea.  â€œWe went to them and said, â€˜If we could make â€˜The […]
content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story discusses spoilers for â€œAnaconda,â€ now playing in theaters

When co-writers Tom Gormican and Kevin Etten first pitched what would become their reimagined take on the so-bad-itâ€™s-good 1997 classic â€œAnaconda,â€ they never thought Sony would be on board with the idea.

â€œWe went to them and said, â€˜If we could make â€˜The Big Chillâ€™ becomes â€˜Anaconda,â€™ then weâ€™d be interested,â€™â€ said Gormican. â€œWe expected them to laugh, [But] they bought it. It was one of those strange pitches where weâ€™re going, â€˜No, no, you guys canâ€™t do this. You canâ€™t.â€™ And theyâ€™re like, â€˜We want to do this with you.â€™â€

Premiering on Christmas, this â€œAnaconda,â€ also directed by Gormican, is not a reboot, remake or even a continuation of the original. While the â€™90s reptilian horror provides a solid springboard for the film, the new â€œAnacondaâ€ is something different entirely, centering not on a National Geographic crew but rather a group of life-long, middle-aged friends who head to the Amazon to shoot their own version of the original film. Stars Paul Rudd, Jack Black, Steve Zahn and Thandiwe Newton soon find themselves fighting for survival against the worldâ€™s largest snake (which is even larger this time around, thanks to CGI). And while it definitely has nods to its predecessor, it was important to Gormican to toe the line carefully.

Popular on Variety

â€œThese are two stories about taking a boat up the river, right?â€ said Gormican. â€œA snake basically slithers on land or in the water. It can either wrap around you or bite you. So youâ€™re locked into the ways that it kills, and youâ€™re locked into a structure of going from point A to point B, which is what this shares with the original storyâ€¦I have a lot of reverence for the original. I love what they did. [But] I didnâ€™t want to play in that sandbox.â€

Instead, they upped the comedic ante, creating what Gormican describes as a â€œbuddy movie that becomes an adventure film that becomes an action film that becomes a horror film.â€ (He cites â€œCity Slickersâ€ and â€œAmerican Movieâ€ as points of inspiration). â€œAudiences are just tired of not seeing original stories,â€ he explained. â€œItâ€™s been a decade of, â€˜Hereâ€™s some remakes of stuff that you used to love,â€™ and thereâ€™s a limit to peopleâ€™s nostalgia.â€

This â€œAnacondaâ€ is also full of meta elements that poke fun of Hollywood itself. Famously charismatic Rudd plays a struggling actor in Los Angeles, and the rag-tag group runs into a â€œrealâ€ Sony crew filming a reboot of â€œAnacondaâ€ who joke about Hollywood having â€œno new ideas.â€ The characters also stumble upon original â€œAnacondaâ€ star Ice Cube, who is on the studioâ€™s snake-destroyed set to reprise his role. When they ask how the writers planned to kill the reptile in their movie, he responds they never finished the script.

â€œIt was mirroring exactly what was happening,â€ said Gormican, who lost two final locations while filming in Australia â€” the first being a factory that then went on strike, and the second being a boatyard the crew had created, only for it to get destroyed by a cyclone. Parts of the latter set actually made it into the movie as they pivoted to end the film using what was left of it: â€œWe went in and made it look [purposefully] destroyed,â€ explained Gormican. â€œAnd we just said it was a snake.â€

And while â€œAnacondaâ€ doesnâ€™t get too sentimental over its source material, it does capitalize on a few familiar faces. In addition to Ice Cube, Jennifer Lopez also has a cameo in the film, where the two actors play themselves. â€œWe were always thinking that it would be fun to have the surviving members,â€ said Gormican, especially once they decided the friends would run into the filming of the reboot. â€œSo we just kept reaching out.â€ Ultimately, both joined in, giving the film their â€œstamp of approval.â€ And, yes, they considered bringing back other â€œAnacondaâ€ actors, though it ended up not making sense to: â€œIf they died in the original, would they be back at the remake if their character was dead?â€

Above all else, with this new â€œAnaconda,â€ Gormican was dedicated to creating a film that felt like fun.

â€œThe thing that Iâ€™ve been missing in my cinema-going experience is a movie for everyone, that plays in a massively fun, adventurous way,â€ said Gormican. â€œPeople lament the loss of the communal feeling of being at a comedy together. And I hope that people get a chance to experience that in this film, and maybe ignite something in a younger generation where they go, â€˜Oh, shit. Thatâ€™s actually something we love to do.â€™â€

title: Ben Folds Does Holiday Music Right, Offering Fans a Very Ho-Ho-Holistic Christmas: Concert Review
summary: Christmas albums still have a bit of a stigma among fans of higher-cred artists. It can be difficult, first, to overcome the expectation that they’re either cash grabs or sops to sentimentality, and secondly, to come up with an original take on seasonal music, even with the best intentions. Should an artist deign to embark […]
content:
Christmas albums still have a bit of a stigma among fans of higher-cred artists. It can be difficult, first, to overcome the expectation that theyâ€™re either cash grabs or sops to sentimentality, and secondly, to come up with an original take on seasonal music, even with the best intentions. Should an artist deign to embark on a full-on Christmas music tour, suspicions might be even more aroused. What, other than opportunism, could be the reason for that much devotion to the season?

So God bless the occasional singer-songwriter like Ben Folds who sees Christmas as a way into writing the kinds of songs he would usually write, not just for the purposes of a new album but a proper concert outing. His recently wrapped Tis the Season tour was a veritable Christmas Star in shining a light on the right path to undertake doing this kind of thing, as was the album of mostly original material that precipitated it, 2024â€™s archly titled â€œSleigher.â€ Folds brings to the concert state a satisfyingly holistic approach to holiday music, give or take a couple of â€œhoâ€™s.â€

Popular on Variety

Even before Folds recorded â€œSleigher,â€ there was a body of solid evidence that he was the right man for the task. That was the fact that heâ€™d already written and recorded a number of songs that mention Christmas or the holidays either prominently or incidentally â€” prior tunes that, combined with the â€œSleigherâ€ material, easily added up to a full set, before getting to any non-seasonal numbers thrown in as bonus tracks for the encore. Most notable of these, as any fan would know, is his late â€™90s hit â€œBrick,â€ a ballad about taking oneâ€™s girlfriend to get an abortion on Dec. 26. Once youâ€™ve written that as your first â€œChristmas song,â€ youâ€™ve established a fine outer parameter for how far youâ€™re willing to stretch the genre, such as it is.

At one of two sold-out appearances at L.A.â€™s new Blue Note Cafe, where he was among the few non-jazz artists booked thus far in the young life of that club, Folds and his combo naturally performed â€œBrick,â€ along with a few other pre-existing holiday songs that tended toward that outer edge, like the novelty songs â€œBizarre Christmas Incidentâ€ and the indelicately titled â€œBitch Went Nutz.â€ But being subversive about Christmas is not actually really his thing, or his current thing, anyway. And the â€œSleigherâ€ album, despite its irreverent name, tends more toward the center, with earnest songs that arenâ€™t afraid to at least skim sentiment, if not indulge in it, even if the sentiment is loneliness. In the overall course of the set, Folds was able to play Christmas for comedy, but more often than not came up for something more earnest, all the way to covering Mel Torme and Vince Guaraldi without apology.

Right at the outset, he explained why he came to see the season as a meaningful setting for original songs.

â€œI like a good rhyme, and thatâ€™s why I guess Iâ€™ve bothered to write a whole Christmas album, plus a few other songs in my past,â€ he told the Blue Note audience. â€œThere were Christmas songs and a whole slew of songs that mention itâ€ in his catalog, â€œand I think the reason is because it is so all-pervasive once a year. It is such a bully of a holiday â€” it takes over everything. Itâ€™s the holiday thatâ€™s too big to fail. And itâ€™s the same shit every year. Itâ€™s the same colors, the same sights, sounds, songs, everythingâ€¦ same adsâ€¦ And thatâ€™s the gift.â€

He would have to further explain that, and did.

â€œBecause when everything is the same and it just feels like a continuation of yesterday, which was 2024, and the day before that was Christmas 2023, the only thing thatâ€™s changed is you. And I think thatâ€™s the reason Iâ€™ve been interested in the topic. You could be at at dinner at Christmas and realize that only two days in Christmas time ago, there were a couple people that used to be here that are not here anymore. And then youâ€™re sitting and talking to nephews who werenâ€™t even here what seems like a couple days ago, and now theyâ€™re bald and telling you about their bankruptcy. Itâ€™s crazy. So, by having that as a marker, it makes it a rhyme. Thatâ€™s what a rhyme is for. It is at the end of a phrase or a couplet to sound the same. Everything seems like it ought to be same, but itâ€™s a little bit different; you actually learned something in the last 10 syllables.â€

Ben Folds at the Blue Note Major Caldwell IV

With that, he went into â€œChristmas Time Rhyme,â€ which, as he explained, was originally supposed to be the title track of his holiday album last year, before â€œI thought of â€˜Sleigherâ€™ and I thought, â€˜Man, I gotta use that. Thatâ€™s better.'â€ Itâ€™s a lovely song tracing those noble thoughts about cyclical thoughts and time speeding up and slowing down and putting us back down where we were, the same and different. And it also puts that poetry aside to cut to the chase: â€œPrecious moments like these, they mean the world to me

/ Listen, youâ€™re all fuckinâ€™ freaks, but weâ€™re family / So we do what it takes to be in one place, if just for a day.â€

Along with the more familiar cover chestnuts that also peppered his set, Folds introduced his audience to â€œYou Donâ€™t Have to Be a Santa Claus (When Christmas Comes Around),â€ a fairly obscure oldie dating back at least to 1955, when the Mills Brothers recorded it. (Folds said it was written during the Great Depression.) â€œI thought it might be relevant these days because itâ€™s about how you might think about helping someone out on other days besides Christmas, and that at the time was a controversial statement, like it is now, to help someone else out.â€

Closer to home, he got at what itâ€™s like to be truly solitary at Christmas â€” or at least other than the companionship of a pet â€” with his original â€œMaurice,â€ written in Nashville in â€œone of those really everything-looks-the-same sort of suburban neighborhoods thatâ€™s not that inspiring. And all the neighbors had the same exact Christmas decorations in their front yard â€” an inflatable Santa thatâ€™s about two stories high and an inflatable reindeer next door; every House down the street almost had the same thing in the front of the yard. Maurice fucking hated the reindeer. He said so many inappropriate things to them in their reindeer languageâ€¦ Our yard was right next to I-40, which comes out here too. And Maurice would dig holes in the snow, and I sort of imagined he was trying to dig a path out.â€

The funnier songs of the past had their own stories. â€œBitch Went Nutzâ€ was about a young, conservative lawyer on the rise inviting a liberal barista to be his date at the office Christmas party, only to have her wind up in a screaming political argument with his right-wing colleagues. â€œBizarre Christmas Incidentâ€ was written as his first misguided attempt at an end-titles theme for â€œHow the Grinch Stole Christmasâ€; he regaled the Blue Note audience with the tale of how horror-stricken the music supervisor was when he turned it in: â€œBen Folds, itâ€™s a fucking kids movie. Iâ€™m not showing this to Ron Howard!â€ He then followed that in concert with the much more appropriate song he turned around in the next 24 hours that successfully made it into the movie, â€œLonely Christmas Eve.â€

Most plaintive was a song he co-wrote with Nick Hornby, â€œPicture Window,â€ about the celebrated novelist and his wife spending New Yearâ€™s Eve with their chronically ill son in a London hospital room. The refrain: â€œYou know what hope is? / Hope is a bastard, hope is a liar, a cheat and a tease / Hope comes near you / Kick its backside / Got no place in days like these.â€ The holiday season doesnâ€™t get any more sobering than that, notwithstanding the Blue Noteâ€™s drink minimum.

What do you do after that full spectrum of holiday fare than sing â€œThe Christmas Songâ€? Along with, come the encore, unseasonal chestnuts from his own catalog, like â€œPhilosophy,â€ from his more keyboard-pounding Ben Folds Era, before circling back to Charlie Brown with â€œChristmas Time Is Here,â€ sung by duet partner Lindsey Craft, to send the audience out into the non-chill on a note of buzzed tranquility.

Folds remains one of our most reliable songwriters, so itâ€™s not surprising that his Christmas material would be as solid as the rest â€” and that he, unlike most of his contemporaries, would recognize that the mass audienceâ€™s hunger for seasonal songs is something worth sating. Because, if nothing else, it does represent a twelfth of our lives, give or take. He has a song called â€œSleepwalking Through Christmas,â€ but itâ€™s to his credit he doesnâ€™t sleepwalk through the task of coming up with this stuff. Hereâ€™s hoping for â€œSleigher 2â€ and a perennial touring season.

content:
SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from Stranger Things 5 Volume 2.

After nearly a decade, Stranger Things fans finally have some answers about the Upside Down and the supernatural forces that have been plaguing Hawkins since Will Byers (Noah Schnapp) disappeared on November 6, 1983.

The second volume of the seriesâ€™ final season unveils most of the secrets that creators Matt and Ross Duffer have been keeping from just about everyone since Season 1, including the fact that the Upside Down has actually been a wormhole to another dimension this entire time.

â€œWeâ€™ve known it was a wormhole since Season 1, but itâ€™s one thing to say it, and itâ€™s another to try to figure out how to visualize such an abstract concept,â€ Ross told Deadline.

Watch on Deadline

The Wormhole

In the first two of three episodes, Nancy (Natalia Dyer), Jonathan (Charlie Heaton), Steve (Joe Keery) and Dustin (Gaten Matarazzo) are searching for clues about what could be behind the massive, flesh-like wall theyâ€™ve discovered surrounding the Upside Down-version of their town. They find answers inside Hawkins Lab, but not the ones they were expecting.

At the end of Episode 5, â€œShock Jock,â€ Dustin discovers one of Dr. Brennerâ€™s (Matthew Modine) journals at the same time that Nancy and Jonathan make it to the roof of the lab to find a mysterious presence floating above it. Dustin realizes far too late that neither Vecna (Jamie Campbell Bower) nor Holly (Nell Fisher) â€” nor anyone for that matter â€” are behind the wall, because the wall is actually holding the whole place together. Before he can warn Nancy and Jonathan, the older Wheeler aims her shotgun at the mass on the roof and sends a sweeping shockwave through the Upside Down, ripping a gash in the wall of the wormhole. Itâ€™s at that moment that viewers finally get a glimpse of what it looks like from afar.

L to R: Joe Keery as Steve Harrington and Gaten Matarazzo as Dustin Henderson in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ 5 Courtesy of Netflix

â€œI think, ultimately, we really wanted it to have that hourglass shape, because we thought that was the simplest way to communicate such a big idea to the audience,â€ Ross explained. â€œBut to do that, we had to zoom out. I canâ€™t remember how many miles away visual effects figured out that we were by the end in order to see the full shape, but we had to go way out.â€

â€œWeâ€™re very far [away],â€ Matt laughed.

Continued Ross: â€œGenerally, we try to stay within the charactersâ€™ perspectives, but that was an instance where we thought to illustrate this best to the audience, we had to leave the charactersâ€™ perspectives for a moment, just to show the enormity of this whole thing.â€

Itâ€™s thanks to Dustin that viewers, and the rest of the crew in Hawkins, wonâ€™t get lost in the theoretical physics of it all. After they make it out of the Upside Down, Dustin draws a diagram on the DJ booth at WSQK to illustrate what theyâ€™re up against. He explains that the mass that Nancy shot was exotic matter, and itâ€™s the only thing keeping the wormhole intact.

â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5 Courtesy of Netflix

â€œ[The Duffers] literally drew that diagram at the season pitch out two years ago, because they understood, even then, that we would need visual aids,â€ Shawn Levy, who directed Episodes 6 and 7 with the brothers, said. â€œIâ€™m so grateful that they had Dustin draw that exact same diagram in the show that the Duffers had used to explain the show years before we shot Season 5.â€

The creators donâ€™t credit themselves with devising that explanation though, nor with the flashlight and slinky that Steve uses to help the group understand how they might use the radio tower to get to the alternate dimension that Dustin has named â€œThe Abyss.â€

â€œOne of our writers, Paul Dictor, his superpower is the harder sci-fi aspects of the show. Heâ€™s read every hard sci-fi book that there is,â€ Matt said. â€œAs far as [when] it comes to this stuff, heâ€™s smarter than Ross and I are, so heâ€™s playing these things, and Ross and I are basically the Steve in the room going, â€˜Huh?â€™ Illustrations help a lot. So we take a lot of those conversations that we have in the room and the way we help everybody understand it and map it onto the show.â€

The Exotic Matter

Speaking of the exotic matter, as Nancy and Jonathan make their way toward the roof, they realize the entire building seems to be melting. Funnily enough, the melting lab was born not from any attachment to accuracy of an encounter with the theoretical sciences, but from a desire to put the characters in a life-threatening situation that may force them to have a conversation that theyâ€™d long been avoiding.

â€œAll we knew was that we wanted the lab to be melting, and weirdly, actually, that idea came less because we thought it was cool, and more from it kind of all revolved around, or started with, that scene between Nancy and Jonathan. We knew we wanted to put them in a life-or-death situation,â€ Matt explained.

After Nancy shoots the exotic matter, the writhing ball of energy becomes even more ferocious, melting the top of the lab at a more rapid rate. She and Jonathan find themselves trapped inside a room as the roof melts around them, threatening to swallow them whole. Itâ€™s at that moment that Jonathan decides to come clean about the engagement ring heâ€™s been carrying around this whole time.

Except, he doesnâ€™t propose. Instead, he admits that he thinks maybe they arenâ€™t meant to be after all, and he believes Nancy knows that deep down as well.

â€œOne of the references was Almost Famous, just like a way less comedic moment than Almost Famous when theyâ€™re on the plane and theyâ€™re about to crash, and they all confess to this, because why not? Youâ€™re about to die. So we liked that moment. Titanic was a slight reference â€” they both now are able to fit on the table,â€ Matt revealed. â€œSo we started from there and reverse engineered what would be a situation that would present that kind of moment for them, and we came up with a melting lab.â€

Then comes the work of actually making the lab look like itâ€™s melting, which required intense collaboration between the visual effects department, production designer Chris Trujillo, and art director Sean Brennan.

â€œIt stressed everybody out,â€ Matt laughs. â€œNobody liked the melting lab idea, not because [of] the concept, but no one actually wanted to do it.â€

The final scene does include some computer-generated visual effects, although the Duffers lament â€œit was intended to be no visual effects.â€

The production had developed a special â€œgoo-like substanceâ€ to funnel into that room so that the scene was entirely practical. Unfortunately, when it came time to produce it at such a large scale, things did not pan out as intended, requiring some post-production magic.

STRANGER THINGS: SEASON 5. (L to R) Gaten Matarazzo as Dustin Henderson and Joe Keery as Steve Harrington in Stranger Things: Season 5. Cr. Courtesy of Netflix /Netflix Â© 2025

â€œI think they tested it in too small of a batch, because by the time we had â€” I donâ€™t know how many gallons of it that were needed to flood that room â€” it was much too thin. I mean, it wasnâ€™t thick at all,â€ Matt recalled. â€œIt was basically gray water, which was a big problem. So Nat and Charlie just acted it out [and] moved more slowly through it, and then we had ILM, who did a lot of visual effects on the final season, [adjust it]. I donâ€™t know how they did it. They developed some sort of formula to fix it and make everything look thick. Obviously, they did all this incredible liquid simulation, at the end of the day. So itâ€™s a real mix between practical and visual effects. Itâ€™s not, maybe, the showiest of our visual effects this season [but it] was one of the ones that blew us away.â€

The Abyssâ€¦and Its Connection to Eleven

The wormhole, Dustin says, connects Hawkins to another dimension that he calls â€œThe Abyss.â€ This is where be believes all of the monsters â€” the demogorgons, the Mind Flayer, Vecna â€” have all been coming from. Itâ€™s also why they havenâ€™t been able to find Vecna in any of their crawls over the last two years. Heâ€™s not in the Upside Down at all. Heâ€™s actually thousands of yards above them, recovering in this alternate dimension, and that is where heâ€™s keeping all those kids, including Holly. Those who have seen The First Shadow may draw connections to one Dimension X.

L-R: Linnea Berthelsen as Kali, Millie Bobby Brown as Eleven, and David Harbour as Jim Hopper in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5 Courtesy of Netflix

Volume 2 does give a glimpse at this other dimension, when Holly briefly escapes Vecnaâ€™s clutches and tries to make a run for it. Outside of his lair, the world looks barren and deserted, save for a few glowing red rifts in the ground where the world is connected to the Upside Down.

Itâ€™s certainly satisfying to get the answers about the Upside Down that have evaded audiences for so long, but, in some ways, all of these explanations come with a new set of questions. What is this alternate dimension? Why is Vecna so hellbent on merging it with the human world? Is this where Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown) sent him all those years ago?

The show has been alluding to the fact that the U.S. governmentâ€™s been locked in some sort of arms race with Russia to access this alternate dimension, likely to use whatever lurks there as weapons of mass destruction. The Vol. 2 episodes also reveal that the government has once again started experimenting on babies in utero to create more supernatural humans like Eleven and Kali, using the latterâ€™s blood. It hasnâ€™t been working, though, which is why theyâ€™ve been after Eleven this whole time. They believe that her blood holds the key to creating more kids like her.

L to R: David Harbour as Jim Hopper and Millie Bobby Brown as Eleven in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5 Courtesy of Netflix

While the pieces are starting to fall into place, there are a couple of dots left to connect on this front, which the Duffers promise will happen in the two-hour finale.

â€œThe goal is to tie up the remaining loose ends and answer any questions that remain,â€ Ross teases. â€œThere are a few specifically big onesâ€¦Henry and his backstory, and then Eleven and what all this means for her and Kali.â€

The Stranger Things finale arrives on December 31.

title: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™ Vol. 2 Explained: What To Remember From Previous Seasons And â€˜The First Shadowâ€™ Play For These Three Episodes
summary: SPOILER ALERT: This post contains major plot details from Volume 2 of Stranger Things Season 5 – Episodes 505-507. content:
SPOILER ALERT: This post contains major plot details from Volume 2 of Stranger Things Season 5 â€“ Episodes 505-507.

Three more episodes of Stranger Things Season 5 have arrived, leaving just the two-hour-plus finale to draw the epic sci-fi series to its close. Volume 2 of the final season gets into the real nitty gritty of what the Upside Down actually is and sets the stage for the final battle with Will (Noah Schnapp), Mike (Finn Wolfhard), Dustin (Gaten Matarazzo), Lucas (Caleb McLaughlin), Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown) etc. vs. Vecna (Jamie Campbell Bower).

Even more so than with Volume 1, Stranger Things: The First Shadow heavily connects to Episodes 505, 506 and 507. As Vecnaâ€™s whereabouts come into focus, Max (Sadie Sink) and Holly (Nell Fisher) happen upon some traumatic memories in his mindscape and he unveils his grand plan with the 12 children he has kidnapped.

Watch on Deadline

Those needing a refresher of what lore has been established in previous seasons need look no further, because like we did with Volume 1, we will explain the connections building up to these three stacked episodes.

Episode 5 â€“ â€œShock Jockâ€

L-R: Caleb McLaughlin as Lucas Sinclair and Priah Ferguson as Erica Sinclair in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Courtesy of Netflix

As viewers learned in the epic cliffhanger ending of Episode 504, aptly titled â€œSorcerer,â€ Will has powers, and as Mike explains them through the lens of Dungeons & Dragons, there difference between his abilities and those of Eleven or Vecna. Will being a sorcerer means that his powers are innate, drawn from a higher being (in this case, Vecna himself). He doesnâ€™t have to study or practice much in order to access his abilities, as evidenced by the relative ease with which he tapped into the hive mind. According to D&D, a wizard has to intensely study to gather intelligence and use their powers. Wizards are reliant on preparation, whereas sorcerers can summon their talent at will.

Particles & The Hive Mind

This connection comes into play when Joyce (Winona Ryder) suggests her son attempt to jack back into the Hive Mind and use Vecnaâ€™s powers against him. In order to do this, the Sinclair siblings come up with two different plans, and Lucas provides a good explanation for the way the hive mind is all connected. While popping some popcorn, he posits that the dormant particles within all hive mind participants can be energized or galvanized to make the connection more apparent. As has been key since Season 2, or really Season 1 when you think about it, particles seemingly from the Upside Down have connected Will, demogorgons, The Mind Flayer and more for better or worse. In Season 2 at the end of Episode 4, â€œWill the Wise,â€ the Mind Flayer infests Will with its shadowy essence, making him â€œThe Spy.â€

Lucas theorizes that these particles were also in Maxâ€™s step brother Billy Hargrove (Dacre Montgomery), when the Mind Flayer possessed him in Season 3, which is why, when the kids trapped him in the pool sauna and cranked up the heat, it exposed inky black veins all over Billyâ€™s body. Similar veins appeared on young Willâ€™s neck in Season 2 when Joyce, Jonathan (Charlie Heaton) and Nancy (Natalie Dyer) did something similar to Will, exposing his body to intense heat to expel the Mind Flayer from his body.

The veins appear on the dead Demogorgonâ€™s body when Robin (Maya Hawke), Will, Mike, Lucas and co. shock the body to provide a way for Will to invade Vecnaâ€™s mind. As of Volume 1â€™s release, the gross fleshy tube that attaches to Will and the 12 childrenâ€™s mouths apparently particalizes them with Mind Flayer molecules.

Vecnaâ€™s Plan

Meanwhile, in his eerily tranquil mindscape, Henry, posing as Mr. Whatsit, tries to persuade the 12 children he has taken that Max is a monster waiting in the woods. According to Henry, she is under control of the Black Thing, like from A Wrinkle in Time (The IT). He wants them to believe she is doing its bidding and would try to enslave the children, too. Sounds like he is really projecting himself and his intentions onto Max. He tells them, though, that his goal is to bring them â€œback to the light.â€

In Season 4, we learned that Eleven sent Henry back to Dimension X, which is the desert-like expanse in which he found The Mind Flayer and demogorgons. He had initially been transported their by powerful technology he stumbled on when he was younger, returning with unexplained abilities. This is where The First Shadow comes into play, because that story fleshes out Henryâ€™s childhood and the moments in Rachel, Nevada, when he stumbled upon the technology â€” weâ€™ll get to this later because the memory itself appears in Episode 6.

Dr. Kayâ€™s Motives

Linda Hamilton as Dr. Kay in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5.

Back with Eleven, Kali (Linnea Berthelssen) and Hopper (David Harbour), viewers learn what Kali knew about Henry â€” everything except that he was still alive. Those who didnâ€™t skip Episode 8, â€œThe Lost Sister,â€ in Season 2 will remember that Kaliâ€™s powers manifest differently than Elevenâ€™s and Henryâ€™s in that she can cast illusions and make the mind see things that arenâ€™t there. She does this while she and El and Hopper get away from the military base in the Upside Down, casting a mirage of herself still connected to that horrific machine she was immobilized in.

Kali reveals that she previously tried to escape her confines, and in doing so, she discovered a series of pregnant woman being infused with her blood. She could tell that it was not having its desired effect, though, because the women were sick and dying and asking Kali for help. She realizes Dr. Kay (Linda Hamilton) was replicating Dr. Brennerâ€™s experiments with blood transfusions in an attempt to create children with super powers. She even cast a vision for Eleven showing Henry hooked up to a pregnant woman, which was â€œPapaâ€™s programâ€ and how he created children like Kali and Eleven (008 and 011), giving them powers through Henryâ€™s blood. She hints that since her blood wasnâ€™t working, Kay is after Eleven for her blood because she could be more like Henry.

Dustin Connects the Dots

Dustin, Jonathan, Nancy and Steve (Joe Keery) have taken it upon themselves to investigate the Hawkins Lab in the Upside Down after Dustin determined that to be the center of the flesh-like wall encompassing the town. In the lab, he finds a map exactly like the one he drew to determine the central point, raising some red flags about the origins of the Upside Down.

He tries to tell Jonathan and Nancy not to disturb what he thought could be a shield generator, similar to the Death Star in Return of the Jedi (1983), but it wasnâ€™t what he thought it was.

We learn throughout these episodes that the characters have been all wrong about what the Upside Down is and whatâ€™s been happening to them since Will disappeared on November 6, 1983. But, some of the most important lore to remember here is actually about Dr. Brennerâ€™s experiments.

See our Vol. 1 mythological explainer if you need a refresher on Season 4 Episode 7, â€œThe Massacre at Hawkins Lab,â€ which continues to heavily come into play in Volume 2.

Episode 6 â€“ â€œEscape from Camazotzâ€

L-R: Sadie Sink as Max Mayfield and Nell Fisher as Holly Wheeler in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5 Courtesy of Netflix

The Duffer brothers teased 506 as an emotional episode, and boy does it deliver while also dispensing truth nuggets that change the perspective of the Stranger Things universe.

Dustin Explains The Upside Down

Gaten Matarazzo as Dustin Henderson in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5

After he and Steve physically brawl, putting their relationship on the brink of collapse, the pair reunite to try and get to Jonathan and Nancyâ€™s aid after Nancy shoots a suspicious force-field atop the roof of the Hawkins Lab in the Upside Down.

Turns out, The Upside Down is a wormhole that bridges Hawkins and Dimension X, where Henryâ€™s powers originated. After going through Dr. Brennerâ€™s mysterious journal that describes the angry red ball as exotic matter holding the wormhole together, Dustin reveals that everything theyâ€™ve thought about the alternate world is wrong and not due to dark magic, but science.

Dustin further diagrams all of this for the entire team in Episode 7.

Vecna Makes Will Spy One Last Time

In â€œShock Jock,â€ Will hacks into Vecna and is able to stall him so that Max and Holly can escape after he threatens to kill Max and trap Holly once again. The invasion gives them enough time to escape, but once Vecna regains control, he uses his connection with Will to find Maxâ€™s body in the real world and send the demodogs after her.

Remember, Will has been â€œspyingâ€ for Vecna, and for the Mind Flayer, since Season 2. We broke that down in our Volume 1 refresher.

Max, meanwhile, is now out in the desert beyond the caves where she sheltered with Holly. She doesnâ€™t know that itâ€™s Will who has overtaken Vecna, assuming itâ€™s Eleven, since sheâ€™s previously witnessed Elâ€™s ability to â€œpiggybackâ€ into other peopleâ€™s minds. Since she and Holly arenâ€™t privy to whatâ€™s going on back home, they have no idea that Will has these newfound powers.

Max & Holly Stumble Upon Henryâ€™s Traumatic Memory

Out in the desert, where Holly draws the connection that the shape of the caves mimics the aperture in the spyglass, an M of sorts, she and Max literally almost fall down a mineshaft. M marks the spot for the reason Henry wonâ€™t venture into the caves â€” they witness his memory of stumbling upon the scientist who had defected from a government experiment. This is where Stranger Things: The First Shadow comes into play.

When Henry finds the scientist, heâ€™s clutching a briefcase that contains stolen technology from an experiment that accidentally sent a group of men to a place theyâ€™ve called Dimension X. We know that Dr. Brennerâ€™s dad was part of this experiment, and itâ€™s basically the entire reason that Brenner has been experimenting on kids â€” to try to recreate that happy accident and get back to Dimension X.

The scientist is very paranoid while Henry, dressed in his boy scout uniform, only wants to help the poor man. After the man shoots Henry in the hand, Henry bashes his skull in out of fear for his life. The young boy opens the briefcase that the scientist attempted to guard with his life. Unfortunately, the camera pans away once he opens the briefcase, and we donâ€™t get to see what happens next, but those that know Henryâ€™s backstory can make some educated guesses.

In Stranger Things: The First Shadow, we learn Dr. Brenner was able to track Henry down because he left his spyglass in those caves. Thatâ€™s how Brenner got Henry in his clutches, realizing that Henry had gone to Dimension X and returned with a unique blood type, a different personality and new powers. Season 4 reveals that Henry was 001, the first child that led to the MKUltra experiments where Brenner created more children with supernatural powers.

Presumably, all the answers about what happened to Henry in those caves are ahead in the upcoming finale.

An Emotional Escape

When Max and Holly make it into the red hellscape in Vecnaâ€™s mind, Max quickly realizes that she and Holly canâ€™t escape together because their bodies are in different places. She gives Holly a rousing pep talk where Holly embraces her little figurine â€” Holly the Heroic â€” that Mike gave her. This helps her move past the fear that froze her when the Demogorgon attacked her mom and when Vecna almost killed Max to believe in herself and her power.

Mind you, this is happening as demodogs close in on Max, Robin, Vickie (Amybeth McNulty) and an unconscious Maxâ€™s body as they hide in a laundry room below Hawkins Memorial Hospital in a scene quite reminiscent of the velociraptors closing in on Lex (Ariana Richards) and Tim (Joseph Mazzello) in Jurassic Park (1993). Lucas doesnâ€™t want to turn off the radio playing Kate Bushâ€™s â€œRunning Up That Hillâ€ because he believes itâ€™s the only thing guiding Max back to him, but the sound tips off the demodogs as to where they are hiding. The song saved Max in Season 4, Episode 4, â€œDear Billyâ€ and she had previously hinted that she could have escaped Vecnaâ€™s mindscape earlier if the tape recording hadnâ€™t needed to rewind. But, as we learn in the final moments of Episode 6, it was never about the song, specifically, but the way it provided her an enduring connection to everything that she loved, which is what really gave her the ability to escape.

Episode 7 â€“ â€œThe Bridgeâ€

L-R: Gaten Matarazzo as Dustin Henderson and Joe Keery as Steve Harrington in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5

â€œThe Bridgeâ€ sets the team up for a crazy confrontation with Vecna as he aims to merge worlds by drawing The Abyss across the wormhole that is The Upside Down.

Holly Wakes Up in Dimension X

After Max wakes up to an emotional welcome from Lucas, Robin and Vickie, we finally learn where Vecna is keeping the 12 children hostage â€” a skeletal looking fortress in an alternate dimension, where they are attached to fleshy feeding tubes. He hangs in the air connected to similar tubes, seemingly drawing energy from the kids. When Holly comes back into her own body, she rips the tube from her mouth, coughs up those pesky black particles and tries to escape from the fortress. Vecna tracks her down and somehow pulls her back from her free fall towards the Hawkins Lab, where Jonathan and Nancy see her briefly before sheâ€™s yanked back into the sky.

Kay Fully Admits Her Big Plan

In a cut to Dr. Kay in The Upside Down lab where she blames Lt. Akers for the kidnapping of the 12 children, Kay screeches that if she had already found â€œthe girlâ€ (meaning Eleven), the demogorgons and other monsters from Dimension X would be in Russia fighting the Soviets, instead of threatening the existence of Americans.

This line is key, because it ties the whole show back around, particularly shining a light on the Russia plot lines in Season 4, where they were opening a gate in Kamchatka to try and replicate the success the Americans had had in harnessing the mysterious powers and beings lurking in these dark dimensions. This further explains why the Russians first came to Hawkins in Season 3 to try and crack open a closed gate underneath Starcourt Mall.

The fight for psychic children and access to the Upside Down and Dimension X can be boiled down to an arms race, of sorts. However, there are still a few missing pieces left to be answered on this front in the finale.

Dustin Diagrams The Upside Down

Back at WSQK, Dustin explains the Upside Down and its connection to a dimension heâ€™s dubbed â€œThe Abyss.â€ D&D players like Erica and Mr. Clarke know The Abyss as a realm of chaos and true evil, and thatâ€™s what this dimension looks to be.

Dustin theorizes that Eleven created the wormhole by making psychic contact with the demogorgon back in Season 1, which did open the gate, or rift, that led to a lot of the creatures coming into Hawkins. As Henry has already explained it vaguely to his prisoners, he wants to merge Dimension X into Hawkins and create a new world.

The team comes up with a plan to counter this action, and Steve Harrington is at the center of it for once instead of being the one who needs an explanation. Using a flashlight and a Slinky, he suggests they wait for Vecna to draw the worlds closer and let him until the top of the radio tower is poking into the dimension, giving them direct access. Dustin adds one note to the plan â€“ to drop a bomb on the Upside Down as they escape one final time and, hopefully, do away with the whole mess.

Willâ€™s Coming Out

Noah Schnapp as Will Byers in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Netflix

In maybe the most heartfelt moment of Season 5 so far, Will braved coming out as gay to not only his close friends but the entire ensemble that has been fighting demons by his side since the day he got taken. This was prompted by a vision Vecna showed Will of a future where his friends worried about him living in a world not friendly to gay men, ultimately pushing his loved ones away as well. Will casted aside the shame so that he was no longer vulnerable to Vecna, who we know preys not just on weakness but specifically on guilt and shame in order to exploit his victims.

Willâ€™s sexuality hadnâ€™t been outright confirmed, but seeds were planted in the earlier seasons when Joyce pointed out the slurs that kids called Will, including queer. Willâ€™s bullies, and even his friends, also often made jokes abut how he didnâ€™t like girls. In Season 3, when Will wanted to play D&D while all his friends would have rather hung out with their respective girlfriends, Mike made a particularly hurtful comment, saying he was sorry Will didnâ€™t like girls.

Willâ€™s acceptance of his own sexuality, as well as his ability to make peace with the fact that Mike will likely not reciprocate those feelings, seems to be key to defeating Vecna in the looming finale.

Aptly set to â€œSilent Night,â€ the video opens with a festive, crackling fireplace, the center of which is not a hearth, bur rather Trump, shown nodding off at various occasions.

â€œWho the hell sleeps in front of the paparazzi, the media? How do you sleep in front of the media? And heâ€™s out cold, you see the dribble coming down the side of his cheek. Who the hell wants to sleep with these people watching? I could never fall asleep under those circumstances. Youâ€™ll never see me sleeping in front of cameras,â€ Trump says in several voice overs, as the Yule log video ironically loops the POTUSâ€™ previous quotes about former President Joe Biden, whom he deemed â€œSleepy Joe.â€

The Daily Show â€” and other late-night shows like Jimmy Kimmel Live!, The Late Show with Stephen Colbert and The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon â€” have made meals out of mocking Trump, who has repeatedly appeared to be dozing off in public, including at a prominent Cabinet meeting. â€œIf you can sleep through that voice [RFK Jr.â€™s], then you are tired, you are fatigued,â€ Kimmel said. In response to the backlash and mockery, White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told the New York Times that the president was â€œlistening attentively and running the entireâ€ early December meeting.

content:
SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from Stranger Things 5 Vol. 2.

The penultimate episode of Stranger Things 5 offers fans a moment that theyâ€™ve been hoping for all season: a reunion between Lucas (Caleb McLaughlin) and Max (Sadie Sink).

At the very end of Episode 6, â€œEscape from Camazotz,â€ Max finally manages to make it out of Henryâ€™s mindscape and wakes up from the coma sheâ€™s been in for nearly two years in the basement of the hospital, where Lucas had brought her to save her from the Demo dogs that Vecna had sent to kill her. The two share an emotional and vulnerable moment together as Max finds her way back to reality.

â€œThat moment, it almost felt real, because I wasnâ€™t around her for so long,â€ McLaughlin told Deadline. Besides a few scenes of Lucas at Maxâ€™s bedside, this was the first moment theyâ€™d shared on-screen all season.

Watch on Deadline

The scene is one of several tear-jerkers in the second volume of episodes, released on Christmas Day. In addition to a whirlwind of emotional sequences, the back half of the season is finally beginning to provide some answers about the Upside Down and the evils that Hawkins has been facing this whole time.

In the interview below, McLaughlin discusses working on these three episodes, including filming that scene with Sink and another equally moving one with Noah Schnapp, and whatâ€™s to come as the beloved series comes to an end.

STRANGER THINGS: SEASON 5. (L to R) Caleb McLaughlin as Lucas Sinclair and Priah Ferguson as Erica Sinclair in Stranger Things: Season 5. Cr. Courtesy of Netflix /Netflix Â© 2025 Courtesy of Netflix

DEADLINE: I hear youâ€™re about to go watch the finale with your castmates. How are you feeling about that?

CALEB MCLAUGHLIN: I have a lot of anxiety and mixed emotions going into it. I think Iâ€™ve been, not uneasy, but Iâ€™m happyâ€¦but then now itâ€™s the last content I will see of the show. So itâ€™s a weird feeling. Not gonna lie, honestly, Iâ€™m like, I want to see it, but I wish it was two weeks ago to where I had more time for the anticipation of it all. But now itâ€™s almost two hours into that moment, and itâ€™s crazy.

DEADLINE: Do you think youâ€™ve made peace with the show ending?

MCLAUGHLIN: I think Iâ€™ve definitely made peace with the show ending. I believe all great things come to an end, and to cherish the moment is for it to end. I think the story has done so well throughout the years, and itâ€™s gonna go down in history as a classic, a show that people loved. Iâ€™m just happy. Iâ€™m happy to be a part of the legacy. So Iâ€™m happy to put this in a nice safe as one of the great things that Iâ€™ve done and move on to the next.

DEADLINE: There is much to discuss from these episodes, but first I wanted to ask you about working with Sadie again on that emotional scene at the beginning of Episode 7 when Max and Lucas are finally reunited.

MCLAUGHLIN: I mean, even her being in the coma in Episode 2, I guess she was still there, but last year, we rarely saw her. That moment, it almost felt real, because I wasnâ€™t around her for so long. You miss your friend when youâ€™re on set. You miss the camaraderie you both have. So I think with that, seeing that emotion that I had [access], to the state of mind that I had to be in, was a different emotion from Season 4, when he was losing her. In this moment, it was more of an emotion of relief and joyâ€¦it wasnâ€™t sadness, it was happiness. But then also, at the same time, that feeling of loss, because now everything that he was feeling, he can now have this release.

DEADLINE: Yeah, almost like he could finally let some of his emotions go after feeling like he had to be strong for her and for his friends for so long.

MCLAUGHLIN: Yeah, he was able to be there for her when that happened. Like, â€˜I never gave up. I never doubted a moment.â€™ And also, like, even I felt that he was still trying to hold it in [when she woke up], because he didnâ€™t want to be the one crying. He had to be strong for her.

DEADLINE: After Max wakes up and they rescue the rest of the crew from the Upside Down, the back half of Episode 7 features some of the first scenes with the entire cast together like this in quite some time. How did those moments feel to film?

MCLAUGHLIN: Oh, man, it was hectic. I think every season, we always have that â€” the beginning, everyoneâ€™s around each other, and then we separate to go on our own journeys, and then we come back at the end. Last season, I was kind of not looking forward to those moments, because usually when we go to those moments, we know the show is ending. When you see everyoneâ€™s face and youâ€™re having a good time, you start realizing time is going by. You see that the time that you had is no longer going to be there. So it was one of those. It was a lot of fun, because I had a lot of fun last season. It was my favorite time filming, because I got closer to everyoneâ€¦ just because of how big the showâ€™s gotten, just these moments towards the end, is so much bigger than any moment weâ€™ve ever had on the show. So I think that was spectacular.

DEADLINE: Can you tell me a little about filming Noahâ€™s coming out scene? Itâ€™s a really emotional scene and one that fans have been anticipating for some time. You all give very emotional and generous performances in that moment.

MCLAUGHLIN: Being on the show for so long, and knowing everyoneâ€™s had other ups and downs and, just me being a friend, just wanting to be there and knowing Iâ€™ll always be there for a friend, I think that scene was a moment that felt genuine. We would be there for Noah. We would be there for anyone in their hard times and their biggest secret moments where they want to be vulnerable. I think itâ€™s important for stories like that to be told, to have those vulnerable moments. I mean, of course, we were acting, but it was important â€” even when we werenâ€™t shown, we were there off screen, we [were] there behind the cameraâ€¦So I think that scene was very special. Noah killed it. His performance was amazing. We had to do it a couple of times, and then we did it on another day as well, and he was able to bring it each time. Being able to be there as his friend, on and off screen, supporting him, especially not even just what the scene is, but just a big moment for an actor to tap into that emotion, I think being there for another actor, being there for a friend is always something that â€” I would want someone to be there for me. So I was just happy to be there in that moment and see him flourish.

DEADLINE: What was your reaction to learning some of the details about the Upside Down and the mythology you all have been building for five seasons?

MCLAUGHLIN: I think it was a whirlwind. It was a lot of shocking moments. I remember reading it and listening to the Duffers read the script. I was like, â€˜Oh, this is good. Oh, yeah. This is how you bring this to a close.â€™ Sometimes TV shows or movies will create something, theyâ€™ll create this world thatâ€™s already good, and then make it more [complicated], and then it becomes less meaningful. I think these moments made it more meaningful, and it made it more grounded.

DEADLINE: How was it to watch it and see what it really looked like? Because thereâ€™s a lot going on that Lucas doesnâ€™t witness, or that none of the characters do, like the wormhole.

MCLAUGHLIN: I didnâ€™t realize that was a thing until I watched it. Thereâ€™s so much detail in this next volume, and thereâ€™s a lot of things you can miss even while reading, because they donâ€™t explain how it is. Itâ€™ll be like a simple sentence, like, â€˜we zoom out and thereâ€™s this wormhole,â€™ right? But then when you see it, you understand what theyâ€™re explaining. Itâ€™s a different perspective. I think thatâ€™s what was sick.

DEADLINE: What can you tease about the finale?

MCLAUGHLIN: Itâ€™ll be our biggest yet. There will be a lot of range of emotions, but youâ€™ll be satisfied with the story.

DEADLINE: What are you looking forward to post-Stranger Things?

MCLAUGHLIN: Iâ€™m excited for the new journey. I think being in the industry, being on the show for so long, thereâ€™s things that youâ€™re like, â€˜oh, I need to do this. I need to do that.â€™ Itâ€™s been full circle to where I realized Iâ€™m already doing it, and I just need to keep doing it and following my heart and knowing who I am, and Iâ€™m excited, because I feel like this is only the beginning in life, in my careerâ€¦future projects next. Literally right after this press tour, Iâ€™m going into another press run for this movie Iâ€™m doing called Goat, an animated movie called Goat. So thatâ€™s the first movie Iâ€™m doing at the top of the year, so thatâ€™s a new beginning, and itâ€™s also a wonderful story about a little goat wanting to be the, no pun intended, greatest of all time. Actually, the pun was intended. But yeah, so Iâ€™m excited for the future.

title: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™ Volume 2 Spoiler Interview: Duffer Brothers Explain the Upside Downâ€™s Origins, Willâ€™s [SPOILER], That Breakup and Why Eleven Might Not Get a Happy Ending

content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers from Season 5, Volume 2 of â€œStranger Things, now streaming on Netflix. After four-and-a-half seasons of questions prompted by â€œStranger Things,â€ in Volume 2 of the showâ€™s fifth and final season, creators Matt and Ross Duffer offered answers aplenty, while also setting up the potentially tragic stakes of the series finale. That deadly new question â€” whether thereâ€™s any world in which Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown) can live without her blood being the key ingredient for future weapons of mass destruction â€” will be answered when the showâ€™s series finale, â€œThe Rightside Up,â€ which drops on Dec. 31. But for now, letâ€™s enumerate the big pieces of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ mythology we now understand after seeing â€œShock Jock,â€ â€œEscape From Camazotzâ€ and â€œThe Bridge,â€ as well as how the show has continued to tie up emotional threads within this tight group of friends whoâ€™ve become a large, extended found family. Top of mind is how Will (Noah Schnapp) finally â€” finally! â€” comes out to his mother, Joyce (Winona Ryder), his brother, Jonathan (Charlie Heaton) and his friends, as they all geared up to head into the Upside Down to fight Henry/Vecna/One (Jamie Campbell Bower) for the final battle. In â€œSorcerer,â€ the climactic conclusion of Volume 1, Will harnessed his connection to Vecna, which had been forged when he was kidnapped into the Upside Down on Nov. 6, 1983. Channeling his Eleven-like powers, Will slayed Demogorgons, stopping them in mid-air, and the episodeâ€™s final image was him wiping his bloody nose (as Eleven does) from the exertion of it. Noah Schnapp Courtesy of Netflix Will had received those powers directly from Vecna: The first scene of Volume 1 revealed that Vecna plugged him into the hive while he was in the Upside Down. Will can use his powers for good, as we see, but Vecna can also use his connection to Will against him. Heâ€™s been creating the tunnels under Hawkins with his mind, using Will as his spy, just as he was in the second season. In Volume 2, Vecna uses Will to spy again to see where Max (Sadie Sink) is â€” a hospital bed in Hawkins â€” which puts her in physical danger. Not wanting any secrets to come between him and his friends, Will decides to come out to them, first by saying, â€œI donâ€™t like girls,â€ and then going on to say that Vecna showed him a world in which he was alone because of his sexuality. â€œIt just felt so real,â€ Will says, through tears. â€œYouâ€™ll never lose me,â€ Joyce tells Will, as Jonathan and then all of Willâ€™s friends say the same, reinforcing their love and support for him before engulfing him in a hug. Other interpersonal storylines resolved in Volume 2 are the ongoing questions of what would happen to Nancy (Natalia Dyer) and Jonathan as a couple, and why exactly Dustin (Gaten Matarazzo) has been so angry at Steve (Joe Keery). After Nancy shoots what turns out to be the exotic matter thatâ€™s holding the Upside Down together, it causes a literal meltdown that threatens to drown them in goo. So, Nancy and Jonathan get real with one another, confessing everything from her hatred of The Clash to the fact that he never applied to Emerson for college (and that she knew). Jonathan takes out the engagement ring heâ€™s been carrying around in a John Coltrane cassette, and says, â€œNancy Wheeler, will you not marry me?â€ They remain, of course, bonded forever â€“ but just as friends from now on. Charlie Heaton and Natalia Dyer Courtesy of Netflix Speaking of friends, after getting into a physical fight in the basement of the lab, Steve and Dustin separate in an angry snit. But after hearing the ruckus on the upper floors, Steve runs up the stairs to help Nancy, recklessly so. Dustin breaks down, saying he canâ€™t lose Steve after heâ€™s already lost Eddie for trying to be a hero. As Dustin sobs, Steve hugs him, finally understanding why Dustin has been protecting himself from getting hurt again by putting up a hostile front. As for the larger â€œStranger Thingsâ€ mysteries, itâ€™s Dustin who figures out, having found the journals of Dr. Brenner (Matthew Modine), that the Upside Down isnâ€™t its own world or own dimension, but instead is a wormhole: a bridge to another world, one that Dustin names â€œthe Abyss.â€ The Abyss, that red, Mars-like space weâ€™ve seen before, is where Eleven sent Henry when she was a small child in Hawkins Lab after he revealed to her that he wanted her by his side in his plot to change (aka destroy!) the world. Itâ€™s where Henry evolved into Vecna, and where, at Brennerâ€™s instruction, Eleven found Henry by using her powers, creating the Upside Down. â€œWhen you made remote contact with the Abyss, the bridge formed,â€ Dustin tells Eleven and the rest of the group as they formulate their plan. â€œAnd ever since, Henry and his army of monsters have been using it to cross right back into Hawkins.â€ The Abyss is also where Vecna retreated after he was nearly defeated in Season 4, Dustin says, to â€œlick his woundsâ€ â€” which is why Eleven couldnâ€™t find him. The show also begins to reveal how Henryâ€™s powers came to be before the Creel family moved to Hawkins in the late 1950s. Max and Holly (Nell Fisher) tour Henryâ€™s memories in an effort to get them out of Vecnaâ€™s mindscape, which Holly has named Camazotz, using the terminology of her favorite book, â€œA Wrinkle in Time.â€ They end up at the bottom of a mine shaft, watching as young Henry comes upon a panicked stranger protecting a silver briefcase â€” he shoots Henry in the hand so Henry, just a child, beats him to death with a rock. (This development is alluded to in the stage play â€œStranger Things: The First Shadow,â€ when Brenner, Henryâ€™s keeper after he murdered his parents, mentions that Henry had been found in a cave in Nevada after going missing on his 8th birthday. After that, Brenner says, Henry was different.) Henry opens the case, but we donâ€™t see what happens after that â€” because Max pulls Holly away. â€œWe will see that briefcase again,â€ Ross Duffer says. â€œYouâ€™re going to get the answers to those questions in the final episode.â€ Nell Fisher and Sadie Sink Courtesy of Netflix Henryâ€™s powers (and their transmissibility) are essential to Elevenâ€™s existential dilemma heading into the series finale. Kali/Eight (Linnea Berthelsen) reveals to Eleven sheâ€™d been held in a military lab because Dr. Kay was transfusing her blood into pregnant women in the hope that the fetuses would eventually develop her telekinetic powers. Thatâ€™s how she learned, Kali then tells Eleven, that Brenner had similarly infused the biological mothers of all the kids in Hawkins Lab with Henryâ€™s blood â€” resulting in Eleven becoming his perfect replica (and the other kids also developing powers). â€œThey will find you,â€ Kali says. â€œAnd they will create more. Like Henry.â€ Those are the stakes of â€œThe Right Side Up,â€ the Duffers say. Is Kali correct in saying that she and Eleven should hang back in the Upside Down as itâ€™s destroyed, removing the threat of them ever being used again as weapons? Or is Mike (Finn Wolfhard) right when he says to Eleven that theyâ€™re the ones who get to decide how things will end? â€œYou, me, Lucas, Will and Dustin,â€ Mike tells her. â€œBecause this is our story.â€

â€œHow can there be a happy ending here?â€ Matt Duffer asks rhetorically. â€œThatâ€™s the question going into the finale.â€

In the interview below, the Duffers delve into that question, as well as writing Willâ€™s coming out scene, when they decided what the Upside Down is, Henryâ€™s backstory, how Max can help Eleven in the series finale â€” and much more.

Noah Schnapp Courtesy of Netflix

Willâ€™s coming out scene! For Volume 1, we talked about how you wanted it to be that as Will â€œbegan to accept himself,â€ heâ€™d be able to achieve the kind of strength he needed to access his powers. Did you always know you wanted Will to have a huge coming out scene with everyone as the final battle approached?

Ross Duffer: Willâ€™s coming out is something weâ€™ve been talking about and wanting to do for a very long time. Originally, it was going to be in Season 4, and we just realized we didnâ€™t have the space to do it properly. And Iâ€™m glad we didnâ€™t, because it really gave us time to arc an entire season toward this â€” toward this one moment. And yes, he is starting to embrace himself, which we see in Volume 1.

Popular on Variety

But what he realizes is that thereâ€™s still something in there that Vecna exploits â€” which is that he hasnâ€™t told anyone about this. That ultimately led to the coming out scene. Originally, it was just going to be Joyce in the original draft of the outline. And the scene was not hitting properly. We realized that Joyce is an important part of this, but he really needed to do it in front of everyone.



How did you work with Noah Schnapp on that scene, both in the writing of it and on the day of filming it?



Matt Duffer: Ross and I spent longer writing that scene, I think, than certainly any other scene this year â€” if not ever. We were so concerned about getting it right. There were a lot of things that went into it. I mean, weâ€™re definitely nervous about how itâ€™s going to go over with everyone. But not as nervous as we were handing it over to Noah. Because ultimately, it needed to resonate and be truthful for him. We really were writing it to and for Noah. He wrote us sobbing after he read it. So it really worked and resonated for him, which was great.

On the day, frankly, there wasnâ€™t really much direction at all. Noah spent a long time â€” I mean, months â€” prepping for that scene, that moment. Luckily, that script was done well in advance. I know he did a lot of work himself. It was a lot of pressure on the day, because not only are you performing this scene that you know is the most important scene for you in the season, youâ€™re doing it in front of not just a crew, but basically all his fellow actors. And they were all there for him. The only thing we said was, â€œHow do you want us to start? Where do you want the camera to be?â€

And most of whatâ€™s in there is the first take. Itâ€™s just one of those moments you always hope for when youâ€™re working with an actor â€” he seemed to access something incredibly truthful. It didnâ€™t feel like he was acting. I think Noah completely lost himself in that scene, and that take is what wound up in the show.

Will doesnâ€™t actually say, â€œIâ€™m gayâ€ â€” the way he frames his coming out is in different ways. Can you talk about how you wanted him to express himself?

Ross Duffer: For us, it was just trying to make sure that the scene felt unique to both Will and unique for a coming out scene. For us, it was about the fears â€” because thatâ€™s what Vecna does. He preys on the fears, which allows us to explore whether itâ€™s someone like Max, whoâ€™s dealing with trauma and depression, or in this case, Will.

The fear is something that Vecna, what heâ€™s talking about, feels really real and grounded to Will, which is not that everyoneâ€™s going to make fun of him or be mean to him. Itâ€™s that everyoneâ€™s going to slowly withdraw from him. Talking about it like that, and then getting the reassurance from them â€” once we had that, then the arc of the scene seemed to make sense, and it felt very specific to both something that Vecna would do, but also to Will as a character. Thatâ€™s when it really clicked, and thatâ€™s why it also helped to have everyone there, as opposed to just Joyce.

Matt Duffer: I would just add that another thing that helped click it for us, and why he says, â€œI donâ€™t like girls.â€ This came about once we added the other actors, his friends, into the scene: Itâ€™s about how they are so similar in every way. Heâ€™s talking about everything they share in common, and how little difference there is between them, and at the end of the day, there is no difference. Theyâ€™re the same people they always were. Thereâ€™s just one thing thatâ€™s different about him. Thatâ€™s what heâ€™s scared of sharing with them. And thatâ€™s why it felt right for him to express it that way.

Linnea Berthelsen and Millie Bobby Brown Courtesy of Netflix

Switching topics! When, in writing the show, did you decide there were two different things, the Upside Down and the Abyss?

Matt Duffer: That was something that I can say was early on. That was all the way back in Season 1: Netflix just wanted us to explain the mythology to them, because we were very adamant early on, â€œWe donâ€™t want to explain it in the show. We like that thereâ€™s mystery, and that thereâ€™s a lot that you donâ€™t understand by the end of the season.â€ They said, â€œThatâ€™s fine, but we would like to know.â€ I think it was actually a really good exercise â€” we spent quite a bit of time with our writers figuring out exactly what the Upside Down was. We wrote a 20-page mythology document. It wasnâ€™t called the Abyss at that point; it was called Dimension X, which is a Ninja Turtle reference.

But yeah, thatâ€™s been in there, baked in there, for a while. Weâ€™ve been holding those cards back for so long; it was a real relief to actually be able to show our hands here.



Can you talk about creating the life and death stakes for Eleven going into the series finale? That if she survives, the military will just continue to hunt her down and make more of her from Henryâ€™s blood?

Ross Duffer: This is one of the reasons we want to bring Kali back â€” thereâ€™s really been dual threats throughout the run of â€œStranger Things.â€ There is the supernatural threat, which is represented by Vecna this season. But the military has always posed a threat, from Season 1 on. Even when Brenner is gone, he gets continually replaced by someone else. In this case, in Season 5, by Kay. So we needed Kali to represent maybe a more pessimistic, but perhaps realistic, version, compared to Mikeâ€™s worldview of weâ€™re gonna have butterflies and rainbows. And Kaliâ€™s going, â€œHow is this going to work? And what is the solution here, that you can live a normal life?â€ Thatâ€™s really a huge part of Elevenâ€™s journey this season.

So did Eleven create the Upside Down? Because this is a debate weâ€™ve been having at Variety since Season 4.



Matt Duffer: Oh! Yes. The answer is yes. Not her fault, I would say!



It was Brennerâ€™s fault.

Matt Duffer: She was forced to do that.

When did you come up with the idea that Brenner had used Henryâ€™s blood to create more Henrys â€” with El being the most successful manifestation of that â€” presumably to be Cold War-era weapons?

Matt Duffer: I think that came about when we were working both on the play and Season 4, if I recall. Because so much of it ties into Henry, into One. Once we started to really explore that, we felt that it was interesting to then use that to explain and delve into where these powers actually originated from.



Is there a way for Eleven not to have Henryâ€™s blood in her?

Matt Duffer: The idea is no, because we like that this is something thatâ€™s in her DNA. Itâ€™s unchangeable. Thereâ€™s no magic antidote thatâ€™s going to solve this issue. And we like that, because it just creates a very complicated, messy situation.

Itâ€™s very easy to say, â€œHey, weâ€™re going to go fight the bad guy and defeat the evil!â€ But even if theyâ€™re able to do that and survive that, thereâ€™s this other, almost even darker, more complicated question on the other side of that.

Joe Keery and Gaten Matarazzo Courtesy of Netflix

How is it that Steve, of all people, came up with the final plan of what theyâ€™re going to do?

Ross Duffer: Well, Steveâ€™s grown up a lot over the years. And particularly this season, heâ€™s been beaten up a little bit by Dustin. Heâ€™s a little behind a lot of time; heâ€™s like Donnie in â€œThe Big Lebowskiâ€ sometimes, where heâ€™s just a step or two behind. But Steve is a smart guy, and I think heâ€™s shown that over the years. As we were working on that penultimate episode, we thought, â€œWho better to come up with the final â€” and arguably the most important plan â€” theyâ€™ve ever had than Steve â€˜The Hairâ€™ Harrington?'â€

Matt Duffer: And his favorite childhood story was â€œJack and the Beanstalk.â€ Thatâ€™s the other thing.

Is the Abyss/Dimension X, the other world where Henry is, the place he originally entered as a child?

Matt Duffer: Correct. Yes. I donâ€™t think in the show we ever call it Dimension X â€” maybe that was in a script, and maybe weâ€™ve referred to that in interviews. But it was never officially Dimension X. So thatâ€™s now always the Abyss, just to keep things as confusing as possible.

Jamie Campbell Bower Courtesy of Netflix

Shawn Levy told my colleague Jenny Maas in a postmortem coming out soon that the answer is no to them being the same thing. He said to ask you guys! He said he doesnâ€™t think the Abyss is Dimension X.

Matt Duffer: Iâ€™m gonna have to text him and clarify this for him.

The man with the briefcase that young Henry meets in that mine shaft â€” is there more to that story of how Henry got his powers that day that weâ€™re going to see in the series finale?

Ross Duffer: Yes, we will see that briefcase again. Youâ€™re going to get the answers to those questions in the final episode.

Matt Duffer: Youâ€™ve only seen half of that core memory.

I wanted to ask about other beats you wanted in Volume 2 as you wound the show down. We talked about Will coming out â€” Nancy and Jonathan figure themselves out, Dustin and Steve make up. Can you just talk about tying up threads and what you felt was essential to do?

Ross Duffer: It was really important for us that all of our characters, as they head into the final battle, have really resolved those tensions or conflicts. That theyâ€™re all working on the same page â€” whether those conflicts are external with others, or internal with themselves. Because in our mind, if the partyâ€™s actually going to be able to defeat this great evil, they have to be all working at the best of their ability, and be all on the same page. So it was important just to resolve those tensions and conflicts. Thereâ€™s one left, really.

Matt Duffer: The Eleven one. The Eleven one is sort of the big outstanding issue that has not been resolved going in finale.

Millie Bobby Brown Courtesy of Netflix

Meaning, can Eleven survive and have the world be safe?

Matt Duffer: Yes, exactly. How can there be a happy ending here? Thatâ€™s the question going into the finale. Is Mike right, or is Kali right?

Can you talk about how you resolved the Nancy-Jonathan story? Like, like an â€œI choose meâ€ situation?

Matt Duffer: Yeah, that was probably the scene we spent the second longest on. Itâ€™s quite a long scene; itâ€™s complicated, what theyâ€™re going through. Itâ€™s very messy, because they do love each other very much, but we always felt that at the end of the day, they need to let each other go in order to grow as people and be independent.

But at the same time, thereâ€™s a very real â€” and I think a lot of people experience this â€” conflict, in the sense that they have gone through something very unique, and in their case, challenging. And how could anyone else ever understand them the way, say, Jonathan understands Nancy or vice versa, having not gone through this? Can they ever form a connection with someone that is as meaningful as this? But also, how do you grow as a person on your own? You need that independence.

So that was the idea behind the scene, and what we really wanted to explore. We had been planning to get there for a while, just figuring out how to exactly articulate that was challenging. But weâ€™re really proud of that scene and, and specifically, how good Charlie and Natalia are.

What was that goo, and why did it stop dripping, or whatever it was doing?

Ross Duffer: We just wanted to put Jonathan and Nancy in a situation where they thought they were going to die â€” and, of course, donâ€™t. But the backstory is that when the exotic matter, or dark matter, is disturbed, it disrupts the environment around, in this case, the lab, causing it to melt. But at a certain point â€” as you see earlier in Episode 5, when Jonathan and Nancy are on the upper levels of the lab â€” they see that this goo, this melted stuff, has hardened. At a certain point, it does harden. And in this case, we show how long it takes.



Matt Duffer: You can think of it like the sun â€” the exotic matter is circular, and then as it dies down over time, the melting slows and stops. The nightmare scenario for Jonathan and Nancy would be end up like those soldiers you saw in the prior episode, where they get trapped.



You guys answered so much in 5, 6 and 7, but â€”

Matt Duffer: The table is set, so to speak, going into the finale. But the big thing is Henryâ€™s backstory specifically, and his connection to the Mind Flayer. So those are the two areas that I think are the most revelatory or impactful as we move into the final episode.

Sadie Sink and Nell Fisher as Holly Wheeler Courtesy of Netflix

How useful can Max be, having spent a year and a half in Vecnaâ€™s mind?



Ross Duffer: Pretty useful, because she knows she knows his memories, and that is where Eleven is going â€” sheâ€™s going into his mind, or into â€œCamazotz,â€ in order to fight him. So I think if Max hadnâ€™t spent all that time there and hadnâ€™t learned her way around, it would make this final battle nearly impossible.

The last time we talked, you still had work to do, and you werenâ€™t there yet in terms of feeling like this experience was coming to an end. Where are you now?

Ross Duffer: Well, we donâ€™t have work to do anymore!

Matt Duffer: Itâ€™s a weird feeling. We finished last week â€” or it was yanked away from us last week. I mean, we would be working on it for another year if we could.

It feels very odd. But on the other hand, weâ€™ve been working on it for three years, and it felt right â€” the right time to let it go. And weâ€™re just excited for people to finally see it.

title: Jamie Campbell Bower Unpacks Vecnaâ€™s Reign Of Terror In â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™ Vol. 2: â€œThere Are Times Where I Feel Wildly Inhumanâ€
summary: SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from Stranger Things 5 Volume 2.
